Ronald Fleury.Action: Looks down sweetly at his son as Kevin talks about family pictures at school.
Makes eyes at the teacher when children ask about his gun, deflecting attention.
Attends son's kindergarten presentation attentively and engages warmly with his son.
Responds calmly and subtly to children's playful but provocative questions about his gun by making eyes at the teacher instead of escalating or dismissing the situation.
Makes eyes at Miss Ross despite her clear disapproval ('no fucking way' hard eye).
Brings his gun into room full of kids but tries to reassure them he is one of the 'good guys' by engaging in a lighthearted interaction.
Is shown in a photo holding his newborn child, described by Kevin as the happiest day of his life.
Makes a confident, somewhat rhetorical statement to a room full of children to assert that he is among ‘good guys’ and thus safe with his gun.
Tries to charm Miss Ross with eye contact but receives a clear negative (hard 'no' eye), indicating a social misjudgment.
Shares a heartfelt, personal story about the birth of his son with a classroom full of children, using engaging and sincere storytelling to connect.
Engages an elementary school class with a clear, vivid, and confident storytelling about a personal and complex event, checking for permission and gauging audience interest.
Executes a rapid, professional attack on the Police Land Cruiser; shoots both occupants swiftly and takes control of the vehicle immediately, demonstrating precision and tactical skill.
Brings snacks and juice boxes to kids at an elementary school, being attentive to them.
Answers a 911 call while mid-juice-pass and quickly walks away from kids, showing responsibility but some level of detachment.
Answers a 911 call promptly despite being in the middle of a social situation, showing responsiveness and situational awareness.
Leaves the children to take the call, indicating prioritization of urgent matters over social niceties.
Shows surprise upon receiving the call, possibly indicating some unpreparedness or being caught off guard.
Smiles at his son despite grim news, kneels to speak to him calmly before leaving for work.
Immediately hardens demeanor upon receiving bad news, showing little emotional processing in front of family.

Immediately shifts to a hard, focused demeanor upon receiving bad news, asks specific, relevant questions about location, timing, and method of attack, shows quick decision to mobilize ('I'm rollin' right now') before ending call and preparing to act.
Balances professional urgency with personal empathy by kneeling to talk to his son and explaining the situation in a calm, age-appropriate manner while readying himself to leave for work.
Smiles warmly and says 'I love you' to his son, kisses his boy's forehead hard.
Shares a look and subtle communication with Lyla showing a quiet, mutual understanding and concern.
Responds to Lyla's worried 'Be safe' with a little Cheshire grin, signaling reassurance despite danger.
Attempts to go see someone despite the danger, showing a willingness to act in a difficult situation.
Gives only a small shrug when asked about his plans, communicating minimal information but maintaining calmness.
Smiles and gives a Cheshire grin in a tense moment, indicating confidence and steadiness.
Does not visibly panic or hesitate despite the surrounding chaos and fear of the situation.
Sits with grieving Glenda and her son Teddy, shows genuine emotional struggle and attempts to comfort them.
Gives a sincere promise to Glenda to take care of the situation and make someone pay, expressing protective intent.
Sits quietly with grieving family members, offers emotional support, struggles to maintain composure but expresses commitment to justice.
Puts a hand gently on Janet Mayes' shoulder and whispers something private to comfort her after announcing the death of a colleague.
Walks purposefully with a folder in-hand, subordinating fury to tasks-at-hand, demonstrating focus under emotional stress.
Enters command center, addresses 50 agents with detailed briefing including casualty numbers and tactical rumors, showing command presence and situational awareness.
Offers personal comfort to an agent grieving a colleague, indicating emotional intelligence alongside leadership.
Puts a hand gently on Janet Mayes's shoulder and whispers comforting words to her in a moment of grief.
Puts a hand gently on Janet's shoulder and whispers something to help her regain composure before a group, showing emotional intelligence and leadership under pressure.
Struggles visibly to maintain control while delivering difficult news, indicating some emotional vulnerability or stress that affects his command presence.
Analyzes bomb blast details and accurately assesses that there was a secondary blast intended to target first responders, demonstrating tactical knowledge and situational awareness.
Admits lack of specific knowledge about the location or nature of the secondary blast device, showing openness rather than overconfidence but revealing a current information gap.
Responds curtly to Adam Leavitt's question with a rhetorical remark ('If you already know the answer Adam, why ask the question?')
Engages attentively with team, crossing names off roster, organizing information methodically
Acknowledges the sophistication and patience of the enemy without emotional judgment, focusing on facts
Questions Adam Leavitt's query in a pointed, confident way indicating a grasp of what is already known.
Crosses off a name on the roster after quick verification from Agent #1 showing decisiveness and reliance on facts.
Summarizes the nature of the attacks accurately and insightfully, recognizing new scale and sophistication.
Calmly reads aloud a memo from the State Department laced with rage, showing concern about the situation.
Circles the names of Mayes and Sykes on the roster attentively.
Carefully reviewing and marking key personnel on the ERT roster, demonstrating attention to detail and situational awareness.
Providing informed, specific intelligence about Abu Hamza, showing knowledge and understanding of the threat.
Calmly reading aloud a memo from the State Department while internally feeling rage, signaling composure under pressure.
Reads memo calmly but with rage; decisively commits to getting access and instructs team to be ready for fast deployment.

Reads the memo calmly but with controlled rage, demonstrates understanding of the political constraints, and decisively states a plan to get access quickly, telling others to be ready for rapid deployment.
Moves quickly out of the room to execute his plan, showing confidence and urgency.

The uncertainty expressed by Adam Leavitt about how Fleury will get access suggests that Fleury's method is not clear to others, which could indicate some opacity, but this is neutral since it doesn’t reflect a failure.
Responds calmly and affirmatively to Director Grace's challenge about handling a difficult situation and keeping quiet.
Defers to Agent Mayes when questioned about her ability to handle the situation.
Provides a clear, detailed briefing explaining the attack strategy and the terrorist’s intent, demonstrating understanding of complex operational details.
Maintains professionalism and uses mild sarcasm to underline the seriousness of the threat, indicating confidence and command of the situation.
Looks expectantly at Gideon Young after the meeting ends, implying he is engaged and ready for further discussion.
Breaks the post-meeting silence by speaking up when most others appear to be wrapping up.
Pushes for clarity about the FBI's perspective despite the meeting wanting to end.
Rejects the idea of vengeance and frames the killings as rational and cold rather than emotional or politically motivated.
Shows respect and gives a subtle nod to Janet Mayes for her contribution.
Shows respect and appreciation to Janet with a subtle nod and words 'Nice work.'
Expresses determination to pursue justice despite risks, mentioning loss of a good friend and desire to do his job.
Dismisses fear for personal safety as weakness in the face of criminal threats.
Explains clearly and confidently the critical importance of acting within 36 hours to catch the killer, demonstrating situational awareness and urgency.
Refuses to be intimidated by danger and insists on engagement despite risks, showing resolve and professional courage.
Acknowledges failures in previous operations but remains focused on the mission, indicating self-awareness and persistence.
Expresses frustration and personal loss while maintaining professional focus, reflecting emotional resilience tied to competence.
His spirited outburst is met with mockery by a superior, hinting at potential challenges in political/organizational navigation and possibly unfiltered frankness.
Shares personal motivation by recalling his high school coach's advice, inviting Grace to join him.
Expresses intense desire for action against perceived injustice but frames it in aggressive terms.
Engages in conversation demonstrating sincerity and openness about his feelings and motivations.
Expresses a strong personal motivation and readiness to act decisively ('I'm fixing to go hit something, boss. You with me?').
Demonstrates understanding of the political and PR implications involving the Saudis and 9-11 hijackers, showing strategic awareness.
Engages in a conversation with Director Grace that reveals thoughtfulness as he digests her caution about vengeance and justice.
Relies on a somewhat simplistic football metaphor ('HIT SOMETHING') as a guiding principle for action, which might indicate a somewhat raw or straightforward approach rather than nuanced strategy.
Engages Elaine Flowers with sensitive information, offers exclusivity and trust by promising to come to her first with real intel.
Pressures Elaine for a favor despite her reluctance, insisting on an exchange.
Engages a skeptical journalist directly and skillfully to gauge her stance and leverage her influence.
Hints at sensitive intelligence and potential leads without fully disclosing, carefully managing information flow to maintain control.
Offers a conditional promise to share critical information first when it becomes actionable to establish trust.
Uses somewhat vague or indirect language about serious allegations, which could be perceived as either careful or evasive.
Tells Elaine that he will come to her first with any real information, implying trust and loyalty.
Describes himself as 'not the nicest kid on the block' and demands 15 minutes alone with Thamer, showing bluntness and a potentially intimidating style.
Refuses to engage in personal explanations with Elaine and simply says he is 'just trying to do my job,' showing a reserved and somewhat distant demeanor.
Politely greets Prince Thamer and expresses desire for cooperation.
Dismisses reporter as exaggerator but tries to present himself as friendly to Saudi Arabia.
Threatens aggressive PR campaign and harsh action against Saudi interests if cooperation is not given.
Engages directly and frankly with Prince Thamer, outlining clear demands and possible consequences.
Demonstrates understanding of geopolitical dynamics and uses strategic communication to pressure the Saudi side.
Takes a moment to think before responding, showing measured and thoughtful communication.
Shows persistence and urgency in pursuing serious threats, emphasizes personal loss of a friend, tries to establish rapport by offering phone use.
Pressure tactics and intense stare down with Prince Thamer to get immediate access.
Presents detailed intelligence connecting funding from Saudi wives to training camps, showing insight and knowledge.
Pressures Prince Thamer effectively with facts about missing girls and casualties, demonstrating confident and strategic negotiation.
Maintains a stare down and offers his phone to bypass communication issues, showing resourcefulness and confidence under pressure.
Waits intensely outside diplomatic building, maintaining composure and readiness during negotiation delays.
Dismisses Prince Thamer's concerns with 'That's too bad.'
Directly challenges the trustworthiness of Saudi Security by asking 'Whose hands?'
Warns Prince Thamer with 'If anything happens to me or my team... It's on you. Understood?'
Engages in tough, sharp negotiation with Prince Thamer, challenging terms firmly and clearly.
Questions Prince Thamer's claim of control,'Whose hands?'
Issues a direct warning: 'If anything happens to me or my team... It's on you. Understood?'
Counters Prince Thamer’s offer with a pointed question about the work-week to clarify terms.
Shows some hesitation momentarily (blinks), indicating occasional uncertainty amidst negotiation.
Thanks Leavitt for volunteering despite Leavitt not volunteering.
Walks onto the plane, leaving others behind on the tarmac.
Walks fast with clear sense of purpose, takes charge in organizing a risky mission despite lack of official approvals and security.
Brings team on a flight to Riyadh despite no approval from State Department, White House, or security, indicating disregard for protocol.
Responds briefly and nonchalantly to Sykes' attempt at friendly conversation, repeating 'I'm good' without elaboration.
"I'm good," he says, getting his bearings during a tense moment before the landing, showing self-assurance and mental readiness.
Repeats "I'm good" with calm confidence when Sykes comments on his demeanor, indicating controlled composure under pressure.
Engages in a candid exchange with Grant Sykes, acknowledges his state despite slight defensiveness, shows some openness to concern.
Checks in with pilots in a friendly, casual manner, answers their questions openly with a bit of dry humor.
Checks in confidently with the pilots about their arrival and landing status, indicating situational awareness and control.
Responds simply and confidently 'I'm checked' when questioned about his psychological state, showing self-assuredness.
Uses humor and metaphor ('hunting... big game hunting') when responding to the pilot's questions, demonstrating ease and confidence in communication.
Has a moment of uncertainty or dismissal when responding to Sykes about his mental status, potentially indicating slight defensiveness or lack of full self-awareness.
Shakes hands politely with Colonel Al-Ghazi and introduces himself formally.
Stands back with the team, dazed and silent observing the caskets draped in flags.
Gives last bit of advice before game-time, 'Heads on a swivel.'
Engages formally and confidently with Colonel Al-Ghazi, shaking hands and exchanging introductions in a professional manner.
Reassures team by normalizing high speed driving as standard operating procedure.
Initiates polite conversation with Colonel Al-Ghazi to ease tension.
States that the vehicle's high speed is standard operating procedure and remains calm, showing situational awareness.
Takes a moment to assess the Colonel Al-Ghazi by engaging him in conversation, demonstrating calmness and interpersonal skill under tension.
Makes a lighthearted comment about Michael Jordan to create rapport.
Uses subordinate (Sykes) to ask difficult questions diplomatically, avoiding direct confrontation.
Maintains control and composure during tense negotiation, lacks direct warmth or friendliness.
Persistently questions Colonel Al-Ghazi despite growing tension, shows determination to seek truth.
Steps in to take charge when team feels tension and uncertainty.
Criticizes Al-Ghazi for not allowing night work despite acknowledged lack of answers, showing frustration.
Quiet and focused, taking everything in.
Calls home and asks sincerely about his wife and son, showing care and concern.
Murmurs 'Saudi slow roll' to himself, possibly indicating skepticism or impatience but no obvious hostility.
Asks what time sunrise is, showing a lack of basic situational knowledge.
Pulls out laptop, quickly wakes it from sleep mode, and contacts family, showing calmness and focus on personal priorities.
Engages thoughtfully and emotionally with his son during a phone call despite being in a tense overseas environment.
Maintains composure and briefly collects himself during the conversation, indicating emotional control.
Begins unpacking immediately after the call, suggesting readiness and preparation in a foreign and presumably high-risk environment.
Interacts with high-level embassy personnel under tense security conditions.
Accepts Prince Bin Khaled's hand held in a friendly, non-hostile manner despite tense circumstances.
Maintains composure silently during the tense greeting and media spectacle, showing neither hostility nor warmth explicitly.
Responds curtly to Sykes' rambling with 'Enough.'
Acknowledges the Prince's invitation with a stunted nod and agrees to attend.
Blanks out camera flashes and glares at onlookers, showing discomfort with attention.
Tries to remain cool when contradicted and ignored by Al-Ghazi.
Tries to remain cool when Colonel Al-Ghazi dismisses his objection and ignores him.
Questions the rules and challenges the statement that they are only observers.
Offers a bottle of water to Al-Ghazi after noticing his breathlessness and hustling back to the Americans
Leans against the door with Sykes, sharing a moment of quiet observation without negative remarks
Asks direct, pointed questions about who is actually in charge of the investigation, challenging the local colonel's authority.
Questions allowance to only 'walk through' the crime scene, indicating concern about proper investigative protocol.
Orders to bring General Abdul-Malik immediately to clarify the confusing chain of command.
Tries to clarify a tense situation and insists on uncovering the truth despite hostility.
Uses sarcasm about killers wearing uniforms and the impact on witnesses, trying to empathize with the innocent witnesses.
Attempts to negotiate directly with Al-Ghazi to talk to witnesses, showing persistence and a cooperative approach.
Displays a tight-grin and looks off, possibly concealing true feelings or discomfort.
Challenges Colonel Al-Ghazi directly and tries to clarify the situation under tense circumstances.
Observes Al-Ghazi carefully, notices subtle emotional cues that inform his approach.
Adjusts tactics by attempting to engage with witnesses through Al-Ghazi, demonstrating adaptability and strategic thinking.
Uses sarcasm and pointed comments about killers wearing uniforms to put pressure on Al-Ghazi.
At one point, tight-grins and looks off, possibly showing internal frustration but does not lose composure.
Sits and listens quietly during an awkward family interview, waves off water offered by Janine.
Asks simple, straightforward questions and chuckles gently during conversation, allowing Janine to share her experience.
Does not visibly react with empathy or reassurance despite family unease and tense atmosphere.
Asks pointed, relevant questions during the interview, such as 'Why Saudi Arabia?' and clarifies details about the safe room incident, demonstrating focus and attempt at understanding.
Accepts defensive answers with minimal follow-up, e.g., responds with 'OK' after Earl's defensive comment about education, possibly missing an opportunity to probe deeper.
Maintains composure and calmly interacts with respondents in an awkward setting, indicating emotional control and confidence.
Asks detailed questions about the situation and location of the Jackson children to gain clarity and insight.
Approaches the Jackson home calmly and identifies himself clearly as FBI to Aaron Jackson, attempting to build rapport.
Appears unsure what to do next after Aaron Jackson's rejection and hostility toward Al-Ghazi.
Asks to come back to support Aaron Jackson, shows hesitance and sensitivity to his pain, avoids eye contact out of respect and discomfort.
Admits he won't pretend to understand Jackson's suffering, demonstrating honesty and humility.
Shows emotional sensitivity and restraint by not pressing Jackson further and avoiding eye contact, respecting his grief.
Asks a relevant and timely question about a traumatic event affecting Jackson's sons, demonstrating awareness and concern.
Appears unsure what to do next in an earlier scene, indicating hesitation or lack of decisiveness.
Takes an instinctive step backward with guard up when confronted aggressively by Aaron Jackson, showing caution rather than aggression.
Politely asks Al-Ghazi if they can tour the compound, showing respect and a desire for cooperation.
Stands silently with Al-Ghazi in front of the Jackson house after a child's scream, sharing a moment of solemnity and recognition of pain.
Takes an instinctive defensive posture when Aaron Jackson aggressively confronts him, showing situational awareness and self-preservation.
Attempts to stay engaged by requesting a tour of the compound from Al-Ghazi, demonstrating initiative and a desire to gather information firsthand.
Observes and investigates the bomb site attentively, noting critical details such as the blood, safety glass, and the gear-shift position, indicating careful and focused analysis.
Quietly pockets a military detonator handed by Sykes without comment.
Quietly pockets a military detonator handed to him discreetly by Sykes, indicating awareness and control of the situation.
Takes in the entire crime scene attentively, showing observational skills and situational awareness.
Calmly instructs a local (Sang) to lower his gun using Arabic, demonstrating respect and clear communication.
Meticulously studies the crime scene and attempts to understand the situation thoroughly without rushing to judgment.
Shows skepticism and careful analysis asking whether the shooters were the local sergeant's men.
Taking in the entire crime scene and instantly lining up the angles while restaging the shootout.
Noticing and identifying a distant four-story building as a potential vantage point over the crime scene.
Communicating effectively in Arabic to correct a comrade's firing position.
Expresses sympathy for the executed police officers by saying 'I'm sorry.'
Engages respectfully with local counterpart Al-Ghazi, following his lead and asking questions.
Focuses on the forensic details and tactical aspects of the investigation without showing obvious interpersonal warmth or friendliness.
Shows respect when addressing Colonel Al-Ghazi, asks politely if they can check out surrounding buildings.
Focuses on tactical and operational details without displaying hostility or arrogance.
Speaks slowly and clearly, aware of his audience and thoughtful in communication; uses charm effectively with Al-Ghazi to gain cooperation.
Casually invites Janet to play hoops, suggesting friendliness and approachability.
Speaks slowly and clearly, cementing his words in his own head as he speaks them; knows when to push and when to ease off; is smooth and highly effective in getting information from Al-Ghazi.
Engages respectfully and strategically with Al-Ghazi to clarify the chain of command even though the answer might take time.
Studies and replays the bombing footage repeatedly, showing focus and professionalism but no evident emotional engagement.
Studies and repeatedly reviews the extremist website footage carefully before proceeding.
Quickly and effectively neutralizes two enemy combatants in four seconds, using precise and confident combat moves.
Shares information and invites Al-Ghazi to examine evidence together.
Observes quietly and reflects on the plan's sophistication without judgment.
Uses video camera to carefully study and compare images with online footage to analyze the situation.
Observes details like discarded trash and deduces the enemy's planning process from subtle evidence.
Successfully convinces Al-Ghazi to see the evidence and think through the enemy's actions calmly.
Smiles small at shared understanding with Al-Ghazi, shows moment of connection.
Offers to help by handing over detonator cautiously to Al-Ghazi, indicating trust and cooperation.
Refocuses conversation with practical, sober statements about the General's abilities without harsh judgment.
Simply nods in response to Al-Ghazi offering televisions, a minimal social engagement.
Effectively uses limited information to gain insights quickly, showing focus and clear thinking.
Skillfully builds rapport and trust by sharing a detonator and offering help, indicating situational awareness and confidence.
Confidently critiques the General's investigative skills, implying his own superior competence in intelligence work.
Challenges the exclusion of Miss Mayes from the event by asking 'You want to tell her that?'
Nods back when told televisions were delivered to his quarters to pass downtime.
Challenges Colonel Al-Ghazi by asking 'You want to tell her that?' in response to the men-only rule, showing defiance and addressing crew morale.
Makes an offhand, somewhat sarcastic comment about the many palaces, 'They all get palaces this big?'
Firmly presents evidence and accuses a suspect in a calm, composed manner aiming to stop further killings and help the Prince.
Delivers serious accusations that cause discomfort and silence among hosts, potentially alienating listeners.

Confidently presents a well-reasoned, insightful argument identifying the mastermind behind the kingdom’s worst crime, using evidence from Colonel Al-Ghazi and his observations to persuade Prince Bin Khaled.
Maintains calm demeanor under pressure and uses tactful language to de-escalate tension while making a bold accusation.
Relies heavily on another person’s (Colonel Al-Ghazi’s) observations to make his case, without personally demonstrating independent verification.
Engages in dialogue acknowledging the complexity of the situation and shows some respect to others' perspectives.
Interrupts Damon Schmidt but then stays silent when overruled, showing restraint.
Asserts credit for his team even in a difficult situation.
Raises his coffee, toasts Damon's cup, joins in a light-hearted bet about setting up a date with Janet Mayes.
Asks Leavitt to tell Janet that she and Damon Schmidt have a date, showing a playful and friendly connection.
Confidently states the strategy to catch Abu Hamza as the way off the island, showing clear focus and understanding of the mission's objective.
Smoothly handles social interaction by turning Damon Schmidt's bet into a confident, light-hearted message for Janet Mayes, indicating composure and social adeptness under pressure.
Suggests photographing the dead shooters and making several hundred copies to distribute, showing initiative and planning.
Proposes splitting up the team to cover more ground, indicating strategic thinking and leadership.
Takes photos of dead shooters and promptly instructs to distribute them to compound security to identify the suspects.
Collaborates effectively with local counterparts (Al-Ghazi) and maintains situational awareness at a complex crime scene.
Engages patiently with family members to gather information, shows observations about their daily life, treats them with respectful curiosity.
Decides to wake up an elderly woman who is sleeping to further the investigation.
Attentively listens to Maddy’s memory, follows her cues, encourages her to elaborate.
Looks to Al-Ghazi for confirmation about the Saudi gardener detail before responding to Maddy, showing cautious verification.
Answers Earl's question about who the identified shooter is with 'That's one of the many things we're trying to find out...', showing honesty and restraint from speculation.
Provides Aaron Jackson with a clinical psychologist's contact to help his traumatized children, showing sensitivity and practical problem-solving.
Promises to find the man responsible for the death of Jackson’s wife, demonstrating commitment and confidence in his mission.
Shows controlled emotional restraint while consoling Jackson, maintaining professionalism.
Nods slightly in satisfaction upon learning from Al-Ghazi that they know the shooter, indicating situational awareness and progress in the investigation.
Slight nod of satisfaction upon confirming a target is on several watch lists.
Engages in dialogue about capturing a target and shows interest in actionable intelligence.
Appears calm and focused rather than displaying undue excitement or rash behavior.
Engages in a reflective conversation with Colonel Al-Ghazi about the consequences of oil and war, showing agreement and understanding.

Expresses sober agreement with Al-Ghazi's pessimism about oil causing destruction, indicating awareness and realistic assessment.
Responds affirmatively and clearly when asked if he understands, showing attentive engagement.
Makes a light joke or sarcastic remark by asking if the other man's first name is 'Colonel,' which shows social confidence and situational awareness.
Half-jokingly comments on unfamiliar surroundings to Al-Ghazi, showing some attempt at light social interaction.
Questions the need to arrest or shoot Talal, showing a moment of hesitation or moral questioning rather than immediate violence.
Observes and comments on the environment with a bit of humor, follows Al-Ghazi as directed without hesitation.
Questions whether they should arrest or shoot Talal immediately upon introduction, showing a seemingly simplistic or impulsive response to a complex situation.
Engages with Al-Ghazi and Talal respectfully, asks probing questions about motivations and mindset of a dangerous enemy.
Uses humor ('How does he know he slept soundly?') in a tense conversation, showing a humanizing attempt.
No overt display of friendliness or sincere emotional connection, remains professional and guarded.
Asks insightful and probing questions about a detainee's motives and background, demonstrating curiosity and critical thinking.
Challenges ambiguous or evasive statements by asking for clarification, indicating engagement and analytical mindset.
Engages patiently with Al-Ghazi and Talal, asks questions to understand their perspective and the situation.
Expresses some confusion but maintains polite and lighthearted tone (jokes about understanding prayer and luck).
Asks pertinent questions about how the terrorists obtain military equipment and how to find the key person.
Tries to understand the cultural nuances but shows some confusion about what 'Prayer. Luck. Handshakes.' means.
Shakes Talal’s hand and carefully inspects the injury (index finger gone), showing attention to detail and situational awareness.
Does not immediately understand the cultural or contextual meaning behind the prayer and luck references, indicating some lack of understanding or awareness.
Responds with focused attention and direct questions to Al-Ghazi's briefing, showing engagement without brusqueness.
Stays at the outer perimeter behind barricades, adhering to police orders without complaint.
Goes about his business as a paramedic is working feverishly on a wounded SWAT officer nearby, showing focus but emotional distance.
Calls Janet over and shares information about the shrapnel, indicating collaboration and straightforward communication.
Maintains focus and composure while paramedics work on a wounded SWAT officer nearby, continuing his own duties without distraction.
Calls Janet for specialized input, seeking to compare shrapnel types, indicating awareness and reliance on expertise.
Moves to help Al-Ghazi toss the room when asked.
Expresses blunt skepticism and disdain about the intelligence ('This is bullshit. You know it. Meaningless. There's no leader here. These are kids. That's it.'), shows frustration.
Cynically comments on the situation and the expected public relations ('Smile for the cameras, body-bag some children. Wrap it up, but us -- out....'), reflecting bitterness and lack of empathy.
Moves quickly to help Al-Ghazi toss the room when instructed.
Questions the significance of the gathered intelligence, calling it 'bullshit' and dismissing it as meaningless because 'there's no leader here, these are kids.'
Expresses cynical resignation about the mission outcome, implying a focus on optics rather than substance ('Smile for the cameras, body-bag some children, wrap it up').
Offers water to Damon Schmidt who looks like he might lose his lunch after seeing dead bodies.
Offers water to a visibly shaken teammate to help him regain composure.
Engages in dialogue to gather information about how their presence was discovered.

Challenges Damon's optimistic assessment of their operation's success by realistically pointing out that the targets were just teenagers manipulated by someone senior, showing critical thinking and skepticism.
Engages directly and thoughtfully in conversation, demonstrating awareness of the political and operational complexities.
Answers the phone professionally, clearly communicates situation, requests warning allies about compromised embassy information.
Engages casually with team members, asks Al-Ghazi for his opinion, shares a moment of reflection about past terrorist attacks.
Is all business and pissed, clearly does not want to join light-hearted beer talk, remains serious and focused.
Engages Al-Ghazi in recalling a previous mission with a sense of frustration about the ease of the catch, acknowledging the small victory.
Expresses determination by saying 'I'll be back' showing a committed attitude but no personal warmth.
Recognizes the enemy's mistake leading to their capture and acknowledges the limited value of the win, showing situational awareness and realistic assessment.
Shows focus and seriousness, ignoring casual banter about beer, indicating professionalism.
Monitors the situation attentively, noticing when a vehicle drops back and questioning its response, demonstrating vigilance and tactical attentiveness.
Instinctively reacts to an imminent threat by taking control of the vehicle to avoid an explosion.
Touches Leavitt's face to check if he is okay after crash.
Tries to claw towards Leavitt and throw punches in defense.
Rips open Grant Sykes' door to rescue him, attempts to free him despite difficult circumstances.
Urgently tries to secure weapons and protect the team during the attack.
Quickly assesses the situation after a vehicle crash, instinctively reaches for his holster despite it being empty.
Commands 'GUN!' to alert others to the lack of firearms and threat presence, indicating situational awareness.
Rips open Grant Sykes' door despite smoke and danger, attempts to rescue him from the wreckage.
Starts sawing off the trapped man's seatbelt with a jagged metal piece, showing resourcefulness and calm under pressure.
Stays composed and instructs the injured man during the rescue ('Hands up -- you're gonna fall'), providing guidance in a critical moment.
Desperately looks toward the fleeing vehicle, indicating awareness of escape but no immediate action to pursue or stop it.
Takes quick control of the situation by grabbing an M4A1 and hustling toward the threat while warning his team to get down.
Switches his rifle to full-auto, takes a deep measured breath, aims carefully, and unloads the entire clip perfectly just before the enemy vehicle reaches the gap, disabling the vehicle effectively.

Keeps close pursuit of Al-Ghazi while under fire, identifies and secures a robust vehicle (Land Rover) for escape and pursuit, helps team members into the vehicle quickly, maintains focus on the target.
Yells clear directional commands promptly under stress (BRAKES-REVERSE-TO THE RIGHT) during a high-pressure ambush.
Swats a grenade out of the vehicle preventing harm to others.
Returns fire to protect his group and provide covering fire.
Stops firing immediately upon seeing two six-year-old boys in the doorway.
Yells tactical information to men on the ground, indicating leadership and communication under pressure.
Drops riot gun and takes an enemy weapon to continue fighting, showing pragmatism and focus on mission rather than care for own comfort.
Spots the RPG launcher quickly and calls it out, immediately engages with accurate gunfire.
Recognizes the enemy is reloading the RPG and improvises by switching tactics to use a grenade at a distance, successfully neutralizing the threat.
Gives clear, direct orders organizing team members to cover specific areas before entering a dangerous building, showing tactical planning and command presence.
Leads the team forward through intense combat, taking primary position, moving steadily and aggressively while protecting his team.
Engages in violent assault without hesitation, showing no evident empathy or concern for the enemy or collateral damage in this excerpt.
Leads the entry through the door, takes primary role, maintains forward motion while firing, adapts quickly to chaotic close quarters combat.
Asks a tense, somewhat philosophical question ('Is Allah on the other side of that door?') before breaching, showing presence of mind under pressure.
Ends fight by striking Huge Man with butt-end of shotgun, saving Janet's life.
Puts hand on Leavitt's head, showing concern for his emotional state.
Cuts Adam's ties to free him.
Asks if everybody is OK, expressing care for others' wellbeing.
Ends a life-threatening fight quickly and decisively with a butt-end swing of the shotgun to the assailant's head.
Checks on the wellbeing of his team with a calm, concise question and quickly assesses the situation, noting multiple enemies remain.
Cuts the ties binding Adam efficiently, enabling an ally’s freedom and operational capability.
Leads the team through a discovered hidden passage into an uncertain environment despite evident danger.
Stands stock still, shows empathy by recognizing the boy as a teenager like his own son, pleads with the boy to drop the weapon peacefully.
Cradles the dying Al-Ghazi, tears spilling; holds his hand in a gesture of solidarity.
Reflects thoughtfully on recent events and expresses admiration for Haytham, shows emotional intelligence and interpersonal awareness.
Responds to Haytham's farewell with a respectful, culturally appropriate statement and handshake, demonstrating social skill and confidence.
Participates in a tense team moment with others, maintaining composure despite visible strain and pressure.
